L2_gloss:
book
Mávapa ohai amo aranduka?
Who wrote that book?

intensive suffix: very
michĩete ― very small
Hesa hovyete. ― His eyes are deep blue.
The 10th letter of the Guaraní alphabet.
The 10th letter of the Guaraní alphabet.

to go
Che ahata che rógape.
I am going home.
a wolf, especially the grey wolf

girlfriend
Ñañemoirũ ramo karai pyharére ikatúntema ñasẽ jaguata tape pytũ ivaivévare, kuñataĩ porã, ñande kichiha, róga rekávo.[1]
to know, to be aware of

Used to form plurals of nouns.
ñandukuéraspiders

Used to form causative of verbs.
mbohérato name, to give a name to
weapon, arm (clarification of this definition is needed)

how many, how much
Mboy jagua rereko?
How many dogs do you have?
to give; to transfer the possession/holding of something to someone else

Used to form causative of verbs.
mopu'ãto raise, to cause to rise
to make grow, to cultivate, to raise a child, to parent

to raise, to lift
Kuimba'e omopu'ã ipo ha oporandu.
The man raised his hand and asked.

no
"Reñe'ẽ piko karaiñe'ẽ?"  "Nahániri."
"Do you speak Spanish?"  "No."

you
Nde reikuaa papapykuaa rehe. ― You know about maths.

Used to form plurals of nouns.
akãnguéraheads

in Guaraní religion, a small chapel for praying
2007,  Juçara Elza Hennerich, Mário Tupã Lopes,  Olhares de guarani para guarani, Gráfica UNICENTRO, →ISBN, page 101:Opy ma ojejapo yvy ra’gui, takua, yvygui, kapi’i gui.(The) chapel is made of wood, bamboo, clay and satintail.

we (exclusive)
Ore roha'ã. ― We (excluding the listener, we and not you) try.
Ñande jaháta okápe ha ore ropytáta ko yvyra pýpe. ― We (all, everyone) will go outside and we (not everyone, just me and some other people) will stay by this tree.

our (possessive determiner of ore)
Kóva ore mbo'ehao. ― This is our (and not your) school.

a, an
Paraguái, ha'e peteĩ tetã mitã pyahu oĩpotáva omohesãi jey, opa yvy apére oĩva ha oikovéva.
Paraguay, a country with young people who are willing to give nature a helping hand.[1]

second-person plural personal pronoun; you
Peẽ peguapy. ― You sit.

culture, way of life
Guaraní rekoGuaraní culture
that (away from both speaker and addressee)

we (inclusive)
Ñande jaikuáama. ― We (all, all of us) already know.
